  • Chapter 2 - Linear Algebra
    • Conditions for a group?
      1. Closure
      1. Associativity
      1. Inverse
      1. Neutral element

      Abelian groups are commutative also.

    • What is a vector space?

      All vectors V(X,+,⋅)\mathcal{V}(\bm{X}, +, \cdot )V(X,+,⋅)﻿, made by adding columns of X\bm{X}X﻿ and multiplying them by scalars λi\lambda_iλi​﻿.

    • What is a vector subspace?

      Vectors generated by addition and scalar multiplication of a subset of vectors in the vector space V\mathcal{V}V﻿.

      Vector subspaces have to meet all conditions for groups.

      i.e. 0\bm{0}0﻿ has to be an element.

    • What are 2 trivial subspaces of a vector space V\mathcal{V}V﻿?

      V\mathcal{V}V﻿ and 0\bm{0}0﻿.

    • Is the solution set of Ax=0\bm{Ax} = \bm{0}Ax=0﻿ a subspace? What about Ax=b\bm{Ax} = \bm{b}Ax=b﻿?
      1. yes.
      1. no.
    • What is rank? What about the rank of the transpose?

      The number of linearly independent vectors in a matrix A\bm{A}A﻿.

      Denoted rk(A)\text{rk}(\bm{A})rk(A)﻿.

      Note rk(A)=rk(AT)\text{rk}(\bm{A}) = \text{rk}(\bm{A}^T)rk(A)=rk(AT)﻿.

    • What are linear mappings?

      A function that converts a vector in one vector space into a vector in another vector space.

      Φ:V→W\Phi:\mathcal{V} \rightarrow \mathcal{W}Φ:V→W﻿.

    • Given a basis for a vector space, how is a coordinate represented in that vector space?

      A coordinate is a linear combination of an ordered set of the basis vectors, B=(b1,b2,⋯ ,bn)B = (\bm{b}_1, \bm{b}_2, \cdots, \bm{b}_n)B=(b1​,b2​,⋯,bn​)﻿.

    • What is a transformation matrix AΦ\bm{A_\Phi}AΦ​﻿?

      An isomorphism matrix, that changes a vector in one basis, to the same vector expressed in a different basis.

    • If we have bases B,B~∈VB, \tilde{B} \in VB,B~∈V﻿ and C,C~∈WC, \tilde{C} \in WC,C~∈W﻿, describe the linear mappings to get the linear mapping A~Φ:V→W\bm{\tilde{A}_\Phi}: V \rightarrow WA~Φ​:V→W﻿ for B~→C~\tilde{B} \rightarrow \tilde{C}B~→C~﻿.

      Where SSS﻿ is a mapping from B~→B\tilde{B} \rightarrow BB~→B﻿, AΦA_{\Phi}AΦ​﻿ is a mapping B→CB \rightarrow CB→C﻿, and T−1T^{-1}T−1﻿ is a mapping C→C~C \rightarrow \tilde{C}C→C~﻿, since TTT﻿ maps C~→C\tilde{C} \rightarrow CC~→C﻿.

    • What is the kernel ker⁡(Φ)?\ker(\Phi)?ker(Φ)?﻿

      The nullspace of the linear mapping.

    • What is the image Im(Φ)\text{Im}(\Phi)Im(Φ)﻿?

      Everything that isn’t the nullspace of the linear mapping.

      • What is a norm? What 3 properties must it satisfy?

        A (vector) norm is a function applied to a vector that maps the vector to a scalar,

        The 3 properties are :

        1. ∣∣λx∣∣=∣λ∣∣∣x∣∣||\lambda \bm{x}|| = |\lambda|||\bm{x}||∣∣λx∣∣=∣λ∣∣∣x∣∣﻿ (Absolutely Homogeneous)
        1. ∣∣x+y∣∣≤∣∣x∣∣+∣∣y∣∣||\bm{x} + \bm{y}|| \le ||\bm{x}|| + ||\bm{y}||∣∣x+y∣∣≤∣∣x∣∣+∣∣y∣∣﻿ (Triangle inequality)
        1. ∣∣x∣∣≥0, and ∣∣x∣∣=0  ⟺  x=0||\bm{x}|| \ge 0, \text{ and } ||\bm{x}|| = 0 \iff \bm{x} = \bm{0}∣∣x∣∣≥0, and ∣∣x∣∣=0⟺x=0﻿ (Positive Definite)

    • 3.3 Lengths and Distances
      • What is the relationship between norms and inner products?

        Inner products induce norms. So you can use an inner product to make a norm. But some norms are not expressible as inner products.

      • What is an example of a norm that isn’t induced by an inner product?

        Manhattan Norm.

      • What is the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality? (in terms of inner product and norm)

        For a specific vector x\bm{x}x﻿, one inner product may produce a smaller output than another, but that doesn’t necessarily suggest that one inner product will always produce shorter values. See the example below.

      • What is a metric? (3 properties)

        d:V×V→Rd :V\times V \rightarrow\Rd:V×V→R﻿

        1. Positive semidefinite. d(x,y)=0  ⟺  x=yd(\bm{x},\bm{y}) = 0 \iff \bm{x} = \bm{y}d(x,y)=0⟺x=y﻿.
        1. Symmetric. d(x,y)=d(y,x)d(\bm{x,y}) = d(\bm{y,x})d(x,y)=d(y,x)﻿.
        1. Triangle Inequality. d(x,z)≤d(x,y)+d(y,z)d(\bm{x,z}) \le d(\bm{x,y}) + d(\bm{y,z})d(x,z)≤d(x,y)+d(y,z)﻿

      • How does applying a transformation with an orthogonal matrix affect a vector?

        It rotates it, or flips it.

        Also, an orthogonal matrix does not affect the length of a vector, and it doesn’t affect the angle between two vectors, if it is applied to both vectors.

    • 3.6 Orthogonal Complement
      • What is an orthogonal complement?

        Let VVV﻿ be a vector space of dimension DDD﻿.

        Let UU U﻿ be a subspace of VVV﻿, with dimension M≤DM \le DM≤D﻿.

        The Orthogonal complement of UUU﻿ is a subspace of VVV﻿ containing all vectors that are orthogonal to all vectors in UUU﻿. It is denoted as U⊥U^{\perp}U⊥﻿ and has dimension D−MD -MD−M﻿. Note U∩U⊥={0}U \cap U^{\perp} = \{\bm{0}\}U∩U⊥={0}﻿.

    • 3.8 Orthogonal Projections
      • What is the definition of a projection?

        Maps higher dimensions to lower dimensions but doesn't move lower dimensions.

        Say pi is your projection operation, pi(pi(x)) = pi(x).

        You can't double project.

      • What is a projection matrix?

        Like an isomorphism matrix, just different.

      • What does Ax=b\bm{Ax} = \bm{b}Ax=b﻿ having no solutions suggest?

      • What is the Ax=b\bm{Ax} = \bm{b}Ax=b﻿ use case for orthogonal projections?

        Apparently used in practice sometimes 🤷, i don’t see why the approximation would be “near” b\bm{b}b﻿, other than that the distance would be minimal. It seems peculiar to me.

      • How would you project onto an affine subspace?

        An affine subspace can be described as a subspace that has been translated by x0\bm{x_0}x0​﻿. So our affine subspace L=x0+UL = \bm{x_0} + UL=x0​+U﻿, where UUU﻿ is a subspace. We also have a vector x\bm{x}x﻿ and we want to find πL(x)\pi_L(\bm{x})πL​(x)﻿.

        First we can get πU(x−x0)\pi_U(\bm{x} - \bm{x_0})πU​(x−x0​)﻿, and then translate it by x0\bm{x_0}x0​﻿ so that it is in L.L.L.﻿

        In the end πL(x)=x0+πU(x−x0)\pi_L(\bm{x}) = \bm{x_0} + \pi_U(\bm{x} - \bm{x_0})πL​(x)=x0​+πU​(x−x0​)﻿. See the image below for visual guidance.

      • What is the determinant of a triangular matrix?

        The product of it’s diagonal entries.

        Given an n×nn\times nn×n﻿ triangular matrix T\bm{T}T﻿:

      • How does a determinant relate to volume?

        The determinant of a matrix is the volume formed by it’s columns:

      • What is the determinant of and n×nn\times nn×n﻿ matrix?

        A recursive function until you get to 2x2 matrices.

        Given a n×nn \times nn×n﻿ matrix A\bm{A}A﻿, if we go along the jjj﻿th column:

        Where Ak,j\bm{A_{k,j}}Ak,j​﻿ is a (n−1)×(n−1)(n-1)\times(n-1)(n−1)×(n−1)﻿ sub-matrix of A\bm{A}A﻿ where row kkk﻿ and column jjj﻿ have been deleted.

        You can similarly apply this to rows iii﻿.

      • What are 7 properties of determinants?
        1. det⁡(AB)=det⁡(A)det⁡(B)\det(\bm{AB}) = \det(\bm{A})\det(\bm{B})det(AB)=det(A)det(B)﻿
        1. det⁡(A)=det⁡(AT)\det(\bm{A}) = \det(\bm{A}^T)det(A)=det(AT)﻿
        1. det⁡(A−1)=1det⁡(A)\det(\bm{A}^{-1}) = \frac{1}{\det(\bm{A})}det(A−1)=det(A)1​﻿
        1. determinants of linear mappings, and other similar matrices are the same.
        1. subtracting or adding a multiple of another row/column to a row/column does not change the determinant.
        1. multiplying a row/column by a scalar multiplies the determinant by that scalar; so det⁡(λA)=λndet⁡(A)\det(\lambda\bm{A}) = \lambda^n\det(\bm{A})det(λA)=λndet(A)﻿.
        1. swapping 2 rows/columns changes the sign of the determinant.
      • What is the trace of a matrix?

        The sum of it’s diagonal elements.

      • What are 6 properties of traces?
        1. tr(A+B)=tr(A)+tr(B)\text{tr}(\bm{A} +\bm{B}) = \text{tr}(\bm{A}) + \text{tr}(\bm{B})tr(A+B)=tr(A)+tr(B)﻿
        1. tr(αA)=α⋅tr(A)\text{tr}(\alpha\bm{A}) = \alpha\cdot\text{tr}(\bm{A})tr(αA)=α⋅tr(A)﻿
        1. tr(In)=n\text{tr}(\mathbb{I}_n) = ntr(In​)=n﻿
        1. tr(AB)=tr(BA)\text{tr}(\bm{AB}) = \text{tr}(\bm{BA})tr(AB)=tr(BA)﻿, A∈Rn×k,B∈Rk×n\bm{A} \in \R^{n\times k}, \bm{B} \in \R^{k\times n}A∈Rn×k,B∈Rk×n﻿, applies to vectors too.
        1. cycles of matrix products all have the same trace, so long as the final product is square. tr(ABC)=tr(BCA)\text{tr}(\bm{ABC}) = \text{tr}(\bm{BCA})tr(ABC)=tr(BCA)﻿.
        1. traces of similar matrices are the same.
      • What is the characteristic polynomial of A\bm{A}A﻿? what about it’s coefficients c0c_0c0​﻿ and cn−1c_{n-1}cn−1​﻿? where the subscript denotes the order of monomial it multiplies.

        c0=det⁡(A)c_0 = \det(\bm{A})c0​=det(A)﻿.

        cn−1=(−1)n−1tr(A)c_{n-1} = (-1)^{n-1}\text{tr}(\bm{A})cn−1​=(−1)n−1tr(A)﻿.

    • 4.2 Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
      • What are co-directed and co-linear vectors?

        co-directed vectors are vectors that point in the same direction (positive scalar multiples of each other.

        co-linear vectors may point in opposite directions, and so are scalar multitples of each other.

      • What is the non-uniqueness of eigenvectors?

        if x\bm{x}x﻿ is an eigenvector, so is αx, α∈R\{0}\alpha\bm{x}, \ \alpha \in \R\backslash\{0\}αx, α∈R\{0}﻿.

      • What is the algebraic multiplicity of an eigenvalue?

        The number of eigenvalues with the same value.

      • What is eigenspace and eigenspectrum?

        eigenspace is span of the eigenvectors associates to one eigenvalue. Commonly it’s just 1 dimensional, but it could be more.

        Eigenspectrum, or just spectrum is the set of eigenvalues.

      • What are 4 properties of eigenvalues and eigenvectors?
        1. The eigenvalues of A\bm{A}A﻿ and AT\bm{A}^TAT﻿ are the same, but the eigenvectors may not be.
        1. The eigenspace of an eigenvalue is also the nullspace of A−λI\bm{A}-\lambda\mathbb{I}A−λI﻿.
        1. The eigenvalues of similar matrices are the same.
        1. Symmetric, posititve definite matrices have only positive, real eigenvalues.
      • How do you find eigenvectors and eigenspaces?

        By substituting your eigenvalue into

        and finding x\bm{x}x﻿ from there. The columns of x\bm{x}x﻿ comprise the eigenspace.

      • What is the geometric multiplicity of an eigenvalue?

        The dimension of the eigenspace of the eigenvalue.

        Can also think of it as the number of linearly independent eigenvectors of the eigenvalue.

        Always less than or equal to the algebraic multiplicity.

      • How does the determinant relate to the eigenvalues?

        The determinant is the product of the eigenvalues.

        Where λi\lambda_iλi​﻿ are the eigenvalues of A\bm{A}A﻿.

      • What does nnn﻿ distinct eigenvalues imply about the eigenvectors?

        There are nnn﻿ linearly independent eigenvectors.

      • What is a defective matrix?

        A matrix with fewer than nnn﻿ linearly independent vectors.

      • How can you obtain a positive, semidefinite matrix from any matrix?

        Let A∈Rm×n\bm{A} \in\R^{m\times n}A∈Rm×n﻿.

      • How can you construct an ONB from a symmetric matrix?

        The eigenvectors of a symmetric matrix form an ONB. If the columns of the eigenspace of one eigenvalue are not orthogonal, you can use Gram-Schmidt orthogonalisation.

    • 4.4 Eigen-decomposition and Diagonalization
      • What is a diagonalisable matrix?

        A matrix A\bm{A}A﻿ that can be expressed as

        Where D\bm{D}D﻿ is a diagonal matrix.

      • What is the definition of Eigen-decomposition?

        Diagonalising a matrix A\bm{A}A﻿ in terms of it’s eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

        Where the columns of P\bm{P}P﻿ are eigenvectors and the entries of D\bm{D}D﻿ are their corresponding eigenvalues. So the eigenvector of the ith row of P\bm{P}P﻿ will have it’s eigenvalue in Di,iD_{i,i}Di,i​﻿.

      • What is an important condition for Eigen-decomposition?

        That P\bm{P}P﻿ has full rank, and hence that there are nnn﻿ linearly independent eigenvectors, where A∈Rn×n\bm{A} \in \R^{n\times n}A∈Rn×n﻿, otherwise we wouldn’t be able to get it’s inverse.

      • Can defective matrices be diagonalized?

        No, look at the question above for more detail.

      • Why is diagonalization useful?

        Because you can raise matrices to high powers efficiently, because

        And Dk\bm{D}^kDk﻿ is easy to find, each element on the diagonal is just to the kth power.

    • 4.5 Singular Value Decomposition
      • What is the definition of a singular value decomposition (SVD)?
      • For which matrices does a SVD exist?

        For all matrices.

      • What makes SVD special in comparison to eigendecomposition?

        First it performs a basis change, then a scaling into a new vector space, then another basis change, whereas eigendecomposition only perfoms a basis change, scales and then undoes the basis change.

      • How is the SVD of a matrix found?

        Let A∈Rm×n\bm{A} \in \R^{m\times n}A∈Rm×n﻿

        Find the Eigendecomposition of ATA∈Rn×n\bm{A}^T\bm{A} \in \R^{n\times n}ATA∈Rn×n﻿.

        The right orthonormal matrix for the SVD is a matrix of the concatenated eigenvectors of ATA\bm{A}^T\bm{A}ATA﻿.

        The singular values, σi=λi\sigma_i = \sqrt{\lambda_i}σi​=λi​​﻿.

        The left orthonormal matrix is the concatenated column vectors of

        For i greater than n, we know that ui\bm{u}_iui​﻿ will be orthonormal and that they’re the eigenvectors of AAT\bm{AA}^TAAT﻿.

    • 6.1 Construction of a probability space
      • How is probability an extension of boolean logic?

        When we have many possible events followed by one another, we have that one event may affect the other in terms of probability. If it’s raining now, it’ll probably be raining in 1 second from now, whereas boolean logic doesn’t have that nuance. In this sense probability extends boolean logic.

        Also we tend to frame many of our beliefs on plausabilities.

Then you can collate multiple into a vector to get a multivariate RV. From there you can apply affine and linear transformations to get your desired multivariate gaussian.

      • What is the Beta distribution? E\mathbb{E} E﻿ and V\mathbb{V}V﻿?

      • What are 4 properties of the Beta distribution for different values of α,β\alpha,\betaα,β﻿?
        1. α=β=1\alpha = \beta = 1α=β=1﻿ - uniform distribution U[0,1]\mathcal{U}[0,1]U[0,1]﻿
        1. α,β<1\alpha, \beta < 1α,β<1﻿ - bimodal with maxima at 0 and 1.
        1. α,β>1\alpha, \beta > 1α,β>1﻿ - unimodal
        1. α=β>1\alpha= \beta > 1α=β>1﻿ - symmetric at 0.5, mean and mode are 0.5
      • What is a conjugate prior and why is it useul?

        Its when the prior is the same type* of distribution as the posterior. This is easier to calculate than when they’re different distributions.

        *Normal, Binomial, Beta etc..

        1. If loss decreases, go back and increase step size, unless that increases loss.*

      • What is a convex function?

        Finding the global minimum of fff﻿, where

        for a scalar 0≤θ≤10 \le \theta \le 10≤θ≤1﻿.

      • What is a convex set?

        A set where the line between any 2 elements in the set is also in the set.

      • What is a concave function?

        The negative of a convex function.

      • What can we say about the gradient and the hessian of convex functions?

        For the gradient

        And f(x)f(\bm{x})f(x)﻿ is convex if and only if the Hessian, ∇x2f(x)\nabla^2_{\bm{x}}f(\bm{x})∇x2​f(x)﻿, is positive semidefinite.

      • What is a supporting hyperplane?

        The hyperplane that makes a boundary for a constrained optimisation problem.

        It’s elements are in the convex set and the convex set is on one side of the hyperplane.

      • What is the Legendre-Fenchel interpretation of duality?

        Defines a convex function and space by hyperplanes, which are tangent to the convex set and hence can be defined as gradients of the objective function.

      • What is the definition of a convex conjugate?

        Usually the inner product is the dot product.

Part II - Machine Learning

  • Chapter 8 - When Models Meet Data
    • 8.1 Data, Models, and Learning
      • What makes a “good” neural network?

        One that performs well on the perfomance metrics we set for it.

        However this is a nuanced, somewhat philosophical question.

      • What are 3 non-conventional (tabular) applications of machine learning?
        1. Social media graphs
        1. Image-text pairs, like captioning
        1. Genomic sequences
      • What processing should you usually do to numerical data?

        Normalisation → set each dimension to zero mean, unit variance w.r.t other examples.

      • What are features/attributes/covariates?

        Input elements; they’re different words for the same thing.

      • What is an example/data-point?

        An full input from the dataset. So a xn\bm{x}_nxn​﻿ is a supervised training (xn,yn)(\bm{x}_n, \bm{y}_n)(xn​,yn​)﻿ pair.

      • What is a label/target/response-variable/annotation?

        The known, true output; yn\bm{y}_nyn​﻿ in the (xn,yn(\bm{x}_n, \bm{y}_n(xn​,yn​﻿) supervised training pair.

      • What are 2 views of a model? What is a predictor?

        A predictor is another word for a model.

        1. As a function f:RD1→RD2f:\R^{D_1} \rightarrow \R^{D_2}f:RD1​→RD2​﻿
        1. As a probabilistic model, essentially a pdf, which is just a special type of function, but we can apply probabilistic rules to it, like bayes rule.
      • What are 3 stages of machine learning algorithms?
        1. Parameter estimation
        1. Hyperparameter tuning
        1. Inference/testing
      • What is inference?

        Testing stage for probabilistic models.

        Sometimes can also mean parameter estimation or testing for non-probabilistic models.

      • What are 2 strategies for parameter estimation?
        1. Empirical risk minimisation - optimisation, numerical methods
        1. Maximum likelihood estimation - optimisation, probabilistic methods (Bayes’)
      • What is the philosophical term for training with regularisation?

        Abduction - Process of inference to the best explaination.

      • What is model selection?

        Tuning hyperparameters essentially.

    • 8.2 Empirical Risk Minimisation
      • What is the general formula for empirical risk minimisation?

        Where we have input X\bm{X}X﻿ and output y\bm{y}y﻿ and model fff﻿. LLL﻿ is our loss function which is always non-negative and it calculates the difference between the labels yiy_i yi​﻿ and our predictions y^i=f(xi)\hat{y}_i = f(\bm{x}_i)y^​i​=f(xi​)﻿.

      • What is the least squares problem?

        The solving of a linear classifier with squared-error loss using normal equations.

      • What is the expected (true) risk?

        The expected loss from the function fff﻿ over all possible* x,y\bm{x}, \bm{y}x,y﻿.

        *Infinitely many.

      • What problem does regularisation solve?

        Solves* the problem of overfitting; by adding a term that penalises parameter size.

        *To an extent.

      • What is a penalty term?

        The regularisation term added to the loss.

      • What is the regulariser in probabilistic models?

        The prior, don’t ask me why.

      • What is (k-fold) cross validation?

        You have your data, you split it into KKK﻿ chunks.

        You use K−1K-1K−1﻿ chunks for training and 1 chunk for validation.

        You use all KKK﻿ possible train-val combinations and get the average validation from there.

      • What is a con and pro of k-fold cross validation?

        Con: you train a bunch of networks.

        Pro: more accurate validation metric and is easily parallelizable so you can just run it quickly on multiple GPUs anyway.

    • 8.3 Parameter Estimation
      • What is the formula for the negative log likelihood?
      • How does log likelihood relate to the least squares problem?

        If the likelihood function is

        where σ2\sigma^2σ2﻿ is for the gaussian noise*, then you can get the negative log likelihood of p, and you end up getting a least squares problem. See below.

        *Which you can assume is always there.

      • What is Maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimation?

        Multiply the likelihood by the prior.

        The prior is gaussian zero mean.

      • What are 4 properties of MLEs in ML?
        1. Can overfit easily (especially with “small” datasets)
        1. Converges asymptotically as N→∞N \rightarrow \inftyN→∞﻿
        1. Variance decreases as N→∞N \rightarrow \inftyN→∞﻿, proportional to 1N\frac{1}{N}N1​﻿.
        1. Need a lot of data.
      • When does overfitting occur?

        When there are way more parameters than are needed to represent the data. See the graph below, of a sin graph estimated by different order polynomials.

    • 8.6 Model Selection

      Introduces validation sets.

      • What tradeoffs do you get when choosing between a smaller and a larger model?

        Smaller datasets are less likely to overfit, but more likely to underfit; and vice versa.

        There’s an occum’s razor idea, where if we have smaller models, the space of datasets it can model is smaller, and so if our dataset is in such a dataset space then the probability of our model being the right one is better, but that’s an abstract SSTTRREETTCCHH in my opinion.   • Chapter 11 - Density Estimation with Gaussian Mixture Models
    • Introduction
      • What is a mixture model?

        A weighted sum of probability distrubtions. Weights are non negative and sum to 1.

      • What is a convex combination?

        A weighted sum where coefficients sum to 1 and are non negative. Doesn’t matter what it’s a weighted sum of, this is a concept.

    • 11.1 Gaussian Mixture Model
      • What is a Gaussian mixture model?

        A mixture model but for gaussians.

    • 11.2 Parameter Learning via Maximum Likelihood
      • Why are GMMs solved one gaussian at a time?

        Well, they aren’t ‘solved’, but because updating many at once is intractible.

        Repeat until reached desired consistency.

        A RV that has a target space of a one hot vector:

        Specifically, vectors that have a 1 somewhere and 0s everywhere else.
